Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Diversity and Evolution of Ectomycorrhizal Fungi of the Guineo-Congolian Rainforest
Award.AbstractNarration:
Some fungi live in close symbiotic association with plants. These ectomycorrhizal fungi provide resources to the plant host, and in return, the plant provides nutrition to the fungi. The interactions of fungi and their hosts provide crucial ecosystem functions including the recycling of nutrients. While the critical roles that fungi play in the environment are well established, their importance in tropical systems is not well understood, and this is especially true for tropical Africa. This project in the Guineo-Congolian rainforest will provide the first thorough documentation of these fungi and plant relationships of tropical Africa using modern methods. The huge forest covering the Congo River basin is one of the last great tropical rainforests of the world. Current threats to the region include logging, mining, and climate change. This project will fill a major gap in our knowledge of the important symbiotic fungi of this ecosystem through expeditionary fieldwork in the undisturbed rainforests of Cameroon. This project is potentially transformative in that if the fungi associated with closely related host plants of Africa and South America are shown to have a common ancient origin, such results would fundamentally impact understanding of the evolution, global biogeography, and local adaptation of ectomycorrhizal symbioses. Additionally, application of new DNA sequencing methods will develop entirely new, phylogenetically informative data that will transform the field. It is estimated that over 100 fungi will be discovered that are new to science. Recognition of these species will greatly inform broader research areas. Key features of the project include student training, internet-based information sharing, and public outreach.

By combining traditional specimen-based sampling with high throughput DNA sequencing, this project will provide the most complete diversity data to date on ectomycorrhizal fungi of Afrotropical forests. Additionally, it will enable comparison of intercontinental tropical ectomycorrhizal fungal communities in corresponding ecosystems. The research will enhance understanding of fungal biogeography in the Gondwana-derived Afrotropical and Neotropical Guiana Shield regions. Survey plots identical to those used for surveys in the Guiana Shield of South America will be established in the Dja Biosphere Reserve and Korup National Park Cameroon and ectomycorrhizal fungi will be sampled using morphological and molecular methods over multiple years. Replication of sample design allows for direct comparisons between Africa and South America, allowing for robust biogeographic analyses to determine the evolutionary histories of ectomycorrhizal taxa in a global context.

POR.DRECONTENT:
OVERVIEW. The Diversity and Evolution of Ectomycorrhizal Fungi of the Guineo-Congolian Rainforest project examined plant-symbiotic ectomycorrhizal (EM) fungi in tropical Africa. Standardized specimen sampling techniques, state of the art DNA sequence-assisted diversity documentation, phylogenomic and phylogenetic analyses, have been employed to examine the origin and diversity of EM mutualisms in the ancient, primeval Guineo-Congolian rainforest. The study sampled EM fungi associated with the leguminous tree Gilbertiodendron dewevrei, which forms monodominant forests that are a defining feature of the region. Permanent survey plots were established and sampled over five years in the Dja Biosphere Reserve of Cameroon. We have employed morphological and molecular taxonomic methods and novel biogeographic analyses to deduce the evolutionary histories of the taxa in a global context. Project research is providing the most complete diversity data to date on EM fungi of Afro-tropical forests and is the first to allow comparison of intercontinental tropical EM fungal communities in corresponding ecosystems.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT. This project has elucidated an ecologically important and poorly studied guild of Afro-tropical fungi. So far over the course of the project we have formally described 29 species new to science, as well as two new genera, and epityped nine previously poorly known Guineo-Congolian species. Continued taxonomic work beyond the timeline of the funded project will yield formal description of at least 100 additional species new to science. Recognition of these taxa is greatly informing broader macrofungal systematics and evolutionary research. Direct support by the project has led, so far, to the publication of 20 peer-reviewed papers in the area of macrofungal taxonomy and systematics and eight papers dealing with tropical forest ecology.

Project research has enhanced understanding of fungal biogeography in the Gondwana-derived Afro-tropical and Guiana Shield regions and formed the basis for broader questions that we are currently addressing concerning the mechanisms controlling diversity and community structure of tropical EM fungi and their host plants. As we work through the data collected during the project, a series of papers will address the transformative question of whether EM fungi associated with closely related EM host plants of the Afro-tropics and Guiana Shield have a common ancient origin, and such results will fundamentally impact understanding of the evolution, global biogeography, and local adaptation of EM symbioses. Additionally, our application of hybrid enrichment genome-level sequencing is providing entirely new, phylogenetically informative loci that will continue to transform macrofungal systematics in general. Overall, the project continues to document many fungal taxonomic novelties from a poorly explored African region, provide DNA sequence data that is greatly enhancing global reference libraries for future studies, and is providing the first rigorous biogeographic analysis of Gondwanan tropical EM fungi.

BROADER IMPACTS.

The project has:

(1) Developed a WWW-accessible database (http://tropicalfungi.org/) with the most exhaustive documentation ever of EM fungal diversity in Afro-tropical and Guiana Shield rainforests, including key fungal and plant taxa.

(2) Has provided taxonomic, molecular biology, and tropical biodiversity research training for a postdoctoral associate, four US or Cameroonian graduate students, six Cameroonian students, and local and 12 indigenous parataxonomists in both Cameroon and Guyana.

(3) Described and curated new EM fungal species and genera, discovered previously unknown lineages of EM fungi and plants, and provided greatly expanded specimen and DNA-sequence resources for globally representative macrofungal systematics and evolutionary research.

(4) Provided outreach activities including 30 formal symposium and conference presentations at national and international meetings.

(5) Provide important information to management agencies in Cameroon on fungal biodiversity and unique EM-dominated habitats that informs their conservation efforts in Guineo-Congolian rainforests, experiencing ongoing environmental threats, including those driven by climate change.
